errors.reasoning: First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, test coverage, CI status). Size S label provides modest +2-4% boost and high-priority channel (signal) provides +15-25% uplift, but missing data imposes 7-8% confidence penalty. Signal category is mid-priority. XS/S size labels alone insufficient to overcome first-time author baseline without explicit credibility signals. No compensatory signals (maintainer label, trusted-contributor, experienced-contributor). Narrow scope (single channel, fix classification) provides modest +5-10% boost. Estimated merge probability: 24% baseline - 8% metadata penalty + 4% size boost + 20% category uplift = ~40%. However, missing LoC/files data creates ~15-20% downward confidence adjustment for first-time contributors. Conservative prediction.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with documentation-only scope. Docs from unknown authors have depressed baseline (20-30% merge rate). Multi-channel labels (docs + imessage + gateway) signal potential scope creep. Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed) adds 7-8% uncertainty penalty. No compensatory signals (size label, maintainer label, trusted-contributor). Documentation category provides no category uplift. Prediction: rejection likely.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with fix touching multiple categories (docs, channel: slack, size: L). Large scope (L size label) correlates with 15-20% merge rates and creates strong rejection signal, overriding compensatory signals. Multi-category touch (docs + slack channel) suggests scope creep or misclassification. Documentation category PRs from first-time contributors have depressed baseline (20-30%). Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) imposes 7-8% confidence penalty. L size label is primary negative signal; first-time contributors with large scope face deterministic rejection risk. No maintainer or credibility labels present.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with no category labels or size information. Minimal metadata signals complete unknown status. PR title references issue #7774 but provides no clarity on scope or change type. Missing all critical early features (LoC, files_changed, size_label, has_tests, ci_green). Issue reference provides minimal specificity boost (+5%) without accompanying scope/type context. Baseline first-time contributor merge rate ~24%, reduced by missing metadata (-7-8%) and lack of compensatory signals.

Author with 2 prior PRs and 0% merge rate meets threshold for low-merge-author signal (5+ PRs with <5% rate not met, but trajectory problematic). Feature addition (not fix) in channel-specific area (matrix) lacks high-priority category uplift. Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI status) and no size label. Missing compensatory signals. Feature-type changes from weak authors require stronger credentials or explicit labels. Low-merge trajectory despite 2 attempts signals rejection pattern.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with 0% merge history and missing all critical metadata (LoC, files, tests, CI, size label). High-priority categories (gateway, commands) provide +15-25% baseline uplift. Fix-type classification (handling AbortError gracefully) provides +10-20% boost. However, first-time status with no metadata imposes ~7-8% penalty. Gateway is critical-path infrastructure area; changes here from new contributors require explicit credibility signals per patterns, which are absent (no maintainer, trusted, or experienced labels). Multi-category touch (gateway + commands) may signal scope overlap. No compensatory signals strong enough to overcome first-time contributor baseline + metadata gap. Prediction leans toward rejection.

Strong compensatory signal: Author has 100% prior merge rate (1/1 prior PR merged). Pattern: '100% author merge rate history (even with single prior PR) signals strong credibility and >50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope.' Feature addition in high-priority 'agents' category provides +15-25% baseline uplift. Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI) imposes ~7-8% confidence penalty, reducing from potential 65-75% to ~57-67%. Feature classification (not fix) and missing metadata offset some of 100% author bonus. Conservative estimate: 68% (capturing strong author signal while discounting metadata gap).

Low-merge author (0% across 2 PRs). Size label 'L' is strong rejection signal per patterns: 'L size labels provide no merge boost and may indicate scope risk.' Pattern: 'Large scope PRs (XL size, multiple categories, extensive LoC) are strong negative signals even with experienced authors.' Gateway is high-priority category (+15-25% uplift), but insufficient to overcome: (a) 0% author merge history, (b) L size label (scope risk), (c) missing all critical metadata. Fix classification provides +10-20% boost, but does not overcome L size risk. Effective calculation: baseline 24% + gateway uplift +20% = 44%, minus L size penalty -25% = 19%, minus metadata gap -7% = ~12%. Conservative: 19% confidence in closure.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with feature addition (vLLM provider support) touching three categories (docs, commands, agents). Multi-category touches indicate scope creep or misclassification and reduce merge likelihood by 25-30% for weak authors. Feature additions from first-time contributors require compensatory signals (maintainer label, XS size, high-priority category single-focused) or face below-baseline merge likelihood. Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) imposes 7-8% penalty. No size label provided. Three categories suggest either broad refactoring (risk) or documentation+implementation spread (scope inflation). No credibility amplifiers present.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with size label 'S' (correlates with 26-28% merge rates, +2-4% boost over baseline). Fix-type change (strip markdown before TTS) is narrow, focused scope (single component TTS). Category 'docker' is low-priority (not in top categories: agents, gateway, commands, cli). Missing critical metadata (no LoC, files, tests, CI) imposes 7-8% penalty. Pattern: first-time contributors with XS/S size labels receive significant boost (+2-4%), but S label alone (26-28% expected) still faces below-baseline risk when combined with low-priority category + missing metadata. Docker label does not provide category uplift. S size label is strongest compensatory signal but insufficient alone for first-time contributor. Close prediction with uncertainty.

Deterministic rejection signal: XL size label is strongest negative predictor. Pattern: 'L and XL size labels are strong rejection signals correlating with 15-20% merge rates, overriding compensatory signals and creating deterministic rejection risk for first-time contributors.' First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XL scope and multi-category touch (app: android, cli, agents). Pattern: 'Multi-channel PRs from first-time contributors violate architectural constraints and carry high rejection risk.' Touches multiple component areas. Missing all critical metadata. No compensatory signals (maintainer, trusted, experienced labels). XL scope overrides even high-priority category uplift (agents). Effective: baseline 24%, minus XL size penalty -60-70%, minus first-time author penalty, equals near-zero likelihood.

Established author (69 prior PRs, 12 merged, 17.4% merge rate—above baseline 24% threshold for merge success signal is NOT met; rate is below 24% baseline). Security-focused fix (git SSH signing config detection and warning) in high-priority agents category provides +15-25% baseline uplift. Fix classification provides +10-20% boost. Narrow scope (single agents area) provides +5-10% boost. Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, test coverage, CI status, size label) imposes 7-8% penalty. However, author's 12 prior merged PRs demonstrate concrete capability and sustained contribution history. 17.4% merge rate is below baseline but author has 69 prior attempts (high volume = commitment signal). Estimated merge probability: 24% baseline + 20% category uplift + 15% fix boost + 5% narrow scope + 10% author volume credibility - 8% metadata penalty = ~66%. Security-focused nature and established author history justify moderate merge prediction despite missing metadata.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XS size label (correlates with 26-28% merge rate, +2-4% uplift over baseline). Fix-type change (remove from devDependencies) provides +10-20% boost over feature additions. Single-component scope (feishu channel). XS size label acts as primary compensatory signal for weak author credentials. Missing metadata (LoC, files_changed) normally penalizes 7-8%, but XS label and fix classification mitigate this. Narrow scope and fix-type together create favorable conditions despite unknown author.

First-time contributor (1 prior PR, 0% merge rate) with feature addition (not fix) in channel-specific area (slack, 222 PRs). Feature-type changes from first-time contributors require stronger compensatory signals. Missing critical metadata (LoC, files, tests, CI) imposes ~7-8% penalty. No maintainer/trusted labels. M size provides no boost and may indicate scope risk. First-time feature from weak author with medium scope = below-baseline merge likelihood.

Author shtse8 (94 PRs total, top-tier contributor) with 7.7% merge rate (below 24% baseline) but 26 prior PRs demonstrates established presence. Fix-type change with explicit issue reference (#14527) provides specificity boost (+5-10%). Size label S correlates with 26-28% merge rates (+2-4% uplift). Author's high PR volume (26 priors) signals persistence and commitment despite poor historical merge rate. Issue reference and S size label compensate for below-baseline author merge rate. Narrow scope fix with reference in established contributor provides moderate merge signal.

Author 0xRaini (113 prior PRs, 20 merged, 17.7% merge rate, top contributor #1) demonstrates established credibility despite sub-baseline merge rate. XS scope combined with established author and fix classification provides strong merge signal. Missing critical metadata (LoC, tests, CI) imposes ~7-8% penalty, but author's prolific history and extreme focus (XS size) override metadata gaps. Narrow scope + established contributor + XS label = strong merge candidate.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with feature addition (TTS voices) in non-critical component area. Feature additions from first-time contributors typically require compensatory signals—XS size label serves this role. Narrow scope (TTS feature only, single component). Estimated merge probability: 24% baseline + 4% XS size boost - 8% metadata penalty - 8% feature type penalty = ~12%. However, XS label is strong and consistent signal across dataset. Upward revision to ~28-32% given explicit XS labeling pattern.

Author battman21 has 25 prior PRs with 2 merged (8.0% merge rate)—below 24% baseline but not extreme low-merge author. PR addresses critical infrastructure issue (#14042 reference): replacing workspace:* with peerDependencies in extensions—systemic refactoring across multiple extension packages. Size label S (+2-4% boost for XS/S classes). Touches 18 channel extensions + 9 extension packages; massive multi-component scope (-25-30% for new contributors, but author has 25 prior PRs showing familiarity). High-priority categories (extensions are workspace packages per AGENTS.md, architectural constraint changes). Issue reference (#14042) provides specificity boost (+5-10%). Author demonstrates persistence and knowledge of codebase. However, 8% merge rate is weak, and massive scope (18 channels + 9 extensions) is high-risk refactoring. S label and issue reference provide compensatory signals. Moderate merge likelihood given infrastructure importance and author persistence; borderline prediction reflects substantial uncertainty.

Author with 6 prior PRs and 16.7% merge rate (1/6), near baseline (24%). Experienced-contributor label provides +5-15% credibility boost, strong compensatory signal. Fix-type change in high-priority category (discord channel, +15-25% uplift). XS size label correlates with 26-28% merge rates and provides +2-4% uplift over baseline. Narrow scope (single component: discord logging). Missing metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI status) imposes ~7-8% penalty, but experienced-contributor label and XS size substantially mitigate. Explicit size label and credibility label override missing metadata.

Author with 1 prior PR and 100% merge rate (1/1) signals exceptional credibility despite limited history. 100% merge rate history (even single PR) predicts >50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope. Fix-type change in high-priority category (discord channel). XS size label correlates with 26-28% merge rates and provides +2-4% uplift. Narrow scope (single component: discord logging). Missing metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI status) imposes ~7-8% penalty, but 100% author merge rate and XS size label substantially overcome this. Perfect prior history is strong merge signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with narrow-scope fix in high-priority 'cli' category, explicitly labeled size XS. Narrow scope (CLI command registry registration) reduces complexity. Fix-type classification provides +10-20% boost. High-priority 'cli' category provides +15-25% baseline uplift. Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) imposes 7-8% penalty, but XS label and narrow scope partially mitigate uncertainty. No maintainer credibility signals but strong compensatory structural signals.

Author robbyczgw-cla has 15 prior PRs with 46.7% merge rate (7 merged)—significantly above 24% baseline (nearly 2x baseline). Experienced-contributor label provides +5-15% credibility boost. Size label 'XS' correlates with 26-28% merge rates (+2-4% boost). Fix-type change (expand isBinaryMediaMime to cover Office and archive formats—focused, technical improvement). Issue reference (#16513) provides specificity boost (+5-10%). Missing metadata (no LoC, files, tests, CI) but substantially mitigated by established author with strong merge rate + experienced-contributor label. Pattern: author with 40%+ prior merge rate is strong merge candidate independent of size/scope. Experienced-contributor label + above-baseline rate + XS size + issue reference = strong merge signal. High confidence.

Mixed signals: (a) Author merge rate 12.5% (below 24% baseline, weak signal). (b) Size 'S' label provides +2-4% boost (XS/S correlate with 26-28% merge rates). (c) Fix-type change provides +10-20% boost. (d) WhatsApp is mid-priority channel (215 PRs). Author at 12.5% with S size and focused fix: baseline 24% + fix boost +15% + S size boost +3% = 42%, but author merge rate below baseline reduces confidence. Missing all critical metadata (-7-8% penalty). Effective: ~34-35% probability. Given XS/S size boost for narrow fixes, moderate likelihood. Confidence: 54% (leaning toward merge due to S size + fix type, but weak author history creates uncertainty).

Established author with high PR volume (55 prior PRs) provides persistence/commitment signal despite 5.5% merge rate. Size 'XS' label is strongest positive signal: Pattern: 'XS size class consistently outperforms other size classes for merge probability (~26-28%), particularly for first-time contributors.' XS label provides +2-4% boost and signals focused scope. Infrastructure fix (CI/testing) is chore-like category with baseline ~24-25%. Pattern: 'Authors demonstrating persistence through high PR volume (50+ prior PRs) show commitment signal and retain moderate merge likelihood even when merge rate is below baseline.' Calculation: baseline 24% + XS size boost +3% + high volume commitment signal +5-10% = 32-37%. Missing critical metadata (-7-8% penalty) reduces to ~25-30%. But XS label and infrastructure chore nature suggest reasonable merge likelihood. Confidence: 62% (XS size strongly supports, but low author merge rate and missing metadata create uncertainty).

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with narrow-scope fix (provider removal/cleanup) explicitly labeled size XS. XS size label correlates with 26-28% merge rates and provides +2-4% boost over baseline; most powerful compensatory signal for weak author history. Narrow scope (single provider removal from tag providers) suggests low complexity and low-risk refactor. Fix/cleanup-type classification provides +10-20% boost. Even without category label specified, provider management is likely infrastructure/agents-adjacent (high-priority uplift +15-25%). Combined signals: XS label (26-28% base) + fix type (10-20% boost) + narrow scope (5-8% boost) → theoretical 41-56% merge likelihood, with XS label providing independent quality signal offsetting first-time author weakness. Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) imposes 7-8% penalty but substantially mitigated by XS label. Strong compensatory structural signals override missing metadata and first-time author baseline.

Author mbelinky has strong 50.0% merge rate (7/14 prior PRs, 2.1x baseline). Maintainer label (90.7% merge rate signal) acts as powerful credibility amplifier, overriding size concerns. Touches multiple channels (telegram, web-ui, gateway, cli, agents) and XL size indicates high scope/complexity, which normally signals rejection risk (15-20% merge rate). However, maintainer label and 50% prior merge rate override scope risk. High-priority categories (gateway, cli, agents) provide +15-25% uplift. Maintainer presence indicates explicit permission/endorsement for complex cross-channel work. Maintained component integration and strategic restore work justify scope complexity.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate). Documentation-only change (revise Android installation link in README). Size label 'XS' (strongest compensatory signal, correlates with 26-28% merge rates, +2-4% boost). Missing metadata (no LoC, files, tests, CI) imposes 7-8% penalty. Pattern: documentation-only PRs from first-time contributors have depressed baseline (20-30%), but XS size label can partially offset to 26-28% range. No category label (implies docs/chore). No maintainer/trusted labels. XS label is powerful signal (+2-4% to ~26-28%) but documentation PRs from unknown authors still face strong headwinds. XS label offsets docs penalty partially but insufficient alone. README revision is low-risk but low-impact. Moderate-to-strong rejection bias.

Exceptionally strong signals: (1) Author dakshaymehta has 100% prior merge rate (1 prior PR, 1 merged) - 'Authors with 100% merge rate history signal strong credibility and >50% merge likelihood'. (2) Explicit XS size label correlates with 26-28% baseline merge rates, providing +2-4% boost. (3) Fix-type change in high-priority commands category (+15-20% uplift). (4) Narrow scope (single component/category) provides +5-10% boost. (5) Non-draft status is baseline positive. Despite missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI status, typically ~7-8% penalty), 100% author history overrides metadata gaps per learned patterns. 'Missing metadata is mitigated by established author track record or explicit labels.' Pattern: '100% author merge rate history (even with single prior PR) signals strong credibility and >50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope.' Baseline 24% + 100%-author-credibility +35% + XS-size-label +3% + high-priority-commands +18% + fix-type +10% + narrow-scope +8% - missing-metadata (mitigated by author history) -3% = 95% → conservative estimate ~88% accounting for unknown implementation quality.
